questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the marked karyotype? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prader-Willi syndrome

 

The karyotype shown highlights a deletion on chromosome 15, specifically involving the long arm of the paternal chromosome. Prader-Willi syndrome occurs when there is a deletion on the long arm of the paternal chromosome 15 (15q11-q13). This genetic disorder is characterized by hypotonia, hyperphagia, obesity, intellectual disabilities, and behavioral problems. The diagnosis is differentiated from Angelman syndrome, which involves a similar deletion but on the maternal chromosome 15.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DiGeorge syndrome: This syndrome involves a deletion on chromosome 22, not chromosome 15. It is characterized by heart defects, immune deficiencies, and facial anomalies.

 

Option C. Cri du Chat syndrome: This disorder involves a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5, characterized by a high-pitched cry, intellectual disability, and distinctive facial features.

 

Option D. Angelman syndrome: This occurs due to a deletion on the long arm of the maternal chromosome 15. It presents with severe developmental delay, frequent laughter, seizures, and ataxia.

 

Educational Objective:


Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15 (15q11-q13), while Angelman syndrome is due to a deletion on the maternal chromosome 15.

questions.text: A 28-year-old P1L1 with irregular bleeding for 1.5 months. What is the next best investigation to do? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) UPT

 

Explanation:

 

In a 28-year-old woman with irregular bleeding for 1.5 months, the first step is to rule out pregnancy. The initial investigation in this scenario should be a urine pregnancy test (UPT). This is crucial because pregnancy-related complications such as threatened abortion, incomplete abortion, or ectopic pregnancy can present with irregular bleeding. Identifying or excluding pregnancy is the most immediate concern and guides subsequent management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TVS (Transvaginal Ultrasound): This is a valuable tool for assessing pelvic pathology and uterine abnormalities, but it is typically done after confirming the UPT results.

 

Option C. Pap smear: This test is used for cervical cancer screening and is not the immediate next step in evaluating irregular bleeding when pregnancy needs to be ruled out first.

 

Option D. USG abdomen: While an abdominal ultrasound can provide useful information, it is less sensitive than a transvaginal ultrasound for early pregnancy detection and pelvic pathology assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a reproductive-age woman with irregular bleeding, the first investigation should be a urine pregnancy test (UPT) to rule out pregnancy-related causes.

choices.text: Unconscious with Pulse present Breathing present
Conscious with Pulse present Breathing present

questions.text: This position is given in which patients? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unconscious with Pulse present Breathing present

 

The position shown in the image is the recovery position. This position is used for unconscious patients who have a pulse and are breathing adequately. The purpose of placing a patient in the recovery position is to maintain a clear airway and prevent aspiration by allowing any fluids (like saliva or vomit) to drain from the mouth. This position also helps prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulse absent, Breathing present: If a patient is pulseless, they are in cardiac arrest and require immediate CPR, not placement in the recovery position.

 

Option B. Pulse absent, Breathing absent: In the absence of both pulse and breathing, the patient requires immediate CPR and advanced life support, not the recovery position.

 

Option D. Conscious with Pulse present, Breathing present: A conscious patient who is breathing and has a pulse would not need to be placed in the recovery position. They should be kept comfortable and monitored, but no special positioning is necessary unless they become unconscious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recovery position is used for unconscious patients who have a pulse and are breathing, to maintain airway patency and prevent aspiration.

questions.text: What will be the level of the anti-Mullerian hormone in low ovarian reserve? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) <1

 

Explanation:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein produced by the granulosa cells of small pre-antral follicles. It serves as a marker for ovarian reserve, reflecting the remaining egg supply in the ovaries.

 

  • AMH in Low Ovarian Reserve: In cases of low ovarian reserve, the AMH level will be less than 1 ng/mL. This indicates a diminished number of remaining follicles and a reduced capacity for fertility.
  • AMH in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): Women with PCOS typically have increased levels of AMH due to the presence of a higher number of small antral follicles.

 

Tests for Ovarian Reserve

 

  1. Biochemical Tests:
    • FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone): Levels measured on Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle are increased in poor ovarian reserve.
    • Estradiol: Day 2 levels are increased in poor ovarian reserve.
    • Inhibin B: Levels are reduced in poor ovarian reserve.
    • AMH: Levels are reduced in poor ovarian reserve.
  2. Ultrasound:
    • Antral Follicle Count (AFC): Done on day 2 or 3 of the cycle. The total number of visible follicles are counted. An AFC greater than 10 is considered normal.
  3. Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test: This test evaluates ovarian reserve by measuring FSH levels before and after administration of clomiphene citrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1-4: Levels of AMH within this range might be seen in women with a moderate ovarian reserve. It is not indicative of low ovarian reserve.

 

Option C. >7: High levels of AMH are often associated with PCOS, where there is an increased number of small antral follicles.

 

Option D. >10: Extremely high AMH levels are usually seen in conditions like PCOS and do not indicate low ovarian reserve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) levels less than 1 ng/mL are indicative of low ovarian reserve.

 

Ref: Page 437, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of a child with cleft lip and palate with microphthalmia and umbilical hernia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Patau syndrome

 

The clinical features described in the question—cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia (small eyes), and umbilical hernia—are characteristic of Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13). Patau syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 13.

 

Children with Patau syndrome often present with multiple congenital anomalies, including:

 

  • Cleft lip and palate
  • Microphthalmia (small, underdeveloped eyes)
  • Umbilical hernia
  • Polydactyly (extra fingers or toes)
  • Congenital heart defects
  • Rocker-bottom feet

 

These features, especially when occurring together, strongly suggest a diagnosis of Patau syndrome.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Edward syndrome: Also known as Trisomy 18, it is characterized by features like micrognathia (small jaw), prominent occiput, overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet. While some features overlap with Patau syndrome, the presence of cleft lip and palate along with microphthalmia and umbilical hernia points more towards Patau syndrome.

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome affects females and is caused by the complete or partial absence of one X chromosome. It is associated with features such as short stature, webbed neck, and gonadal dysgenesis, but not with cleft lip, palate, or microphthalmia.

 

Option D. Prader-Willi syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by hypotonia, poor feeding in infancy, obesity, intellectual disability, and hypogonadism, but not by cleft lip and palate or microphthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) presents with multiple congenital anomalies, including cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia, and umbilical hernia, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A firefighter with a history of smoke inhalation presents with fever, cough, and signs of lung consolidation. Sputum culture reveals colonies with a green pigment and fluorescence under UV light. Which organism is most likely? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

The key diagnostic features here are the green pigment (pyocyanin) and fluorescence under UV light, which are characteristic of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Pyocyanin is a diffusible pigment that gives colonies their distinctive green color. The history of smoke inhalation is also relevant as P. aeruginosa commonly causes opportunistic infections in damaged airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae produces alpha-hemolytic colonies without pigment or fluorescence

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: Klebsiella pneumoniae produces mucoid colonies without pigment or fluorescence

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus produces golden-yellow colonies without fluorescence

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa's characteristic laboratory features: green pigment (pyocyanin) production and fluorescence under UV light, particularly in the context of respiratory infections following airway damage.

questions.text: Samter’s triad refers to the association of Aspirin-sensitive asthma and: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasal polyp

 

Explanation:

 

Samter's triad (also called AERD - Aspirin Exacerbated Respiratory Disease) consists of nasal polyps, bronchial asthma, and aspirin hypersensitivity. This classic triad represents a specific phenotype of asthma that often presents with severe symptoms and can be challenging to manage due to the multiple body systems involved and the potential for severe reactions to NSAIDs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obesity: While obesity can be associated with asthma and may contribute to its severity, it is not a component of Samter's triad. Obesity is a risk factor for OSA and can worsen asthma control, but it's not part of this specific syndrome.

 

Option B. Urticaria: Urticaria (hives) is not part of Samter's triad. While aspirin sensitivity can sometimes cause urticaria in some patients, it's not a defining feature of Samter's triad which specifically involves the respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Rhinosinusitis: While patients with Samter's triad frequently have chronic rhinosinusitis, the specific defining feature mentioned in the triad is nasal polyps, not rhinosinusitis itself. Nasal polyps represent a more specific pathological finding.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Samter's triad is the specific association of three clinical entities: nasal polyps, bronchial asthma, and aspirin hypersensitivity, representing a distinct clinical syndrome requiring specific management considerations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of depression was initially being treated with sertraline, but his symptoms were not adequately controlled. His medication regimen was changed to include an MAO inhibitor and amitriptyline. Shortly after the change in medication, the patient developed agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyproheptadine

  

The patient’s symptoms of agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors are indicative of serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition that occurs due to excessive serotonergic activity in the nervous system, usually as a result of combining medications that increase serotonin levels, such as SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, and TCAs. In this case, the combination of sertraline (an SSRI), an MAO inhibitor, and amitriptyline (a TCA) significantly increases serotonin, leading to the development of serotonin syndrome.

 

Symptoms of Serotonin Syndrome: (Mnemonic – RASH D)

 

  • Restlessness
  • Agitation
  • Seizures
  • Hyperreflexia
  • Diarrhea

 

Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with serotonin receptor antagonist properties, making it the drug of choice for treating serotonin syndrome. It works by blocking serotonin receptors, thereby reducing the excessive serotonergic activity causing the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. Lorazepam: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine used to manage agitation and seizures but does not directly treat the underlying cause of serotonin syndrome. It is used as supportive therapy but is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. L-carnitine: L-carnitine is a supplement often used in metabolic conditions and does not play a role in treating serotonin syndrome. It has no effect on serotonin levels or receptor activity.

 

Option D. Leucovorin: Leucovorin is a form of folic acid used as a rescue agent in methotrexate toxicity and other specific conditions. It has no role in the management of serotonin syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin syndrome can occur when serotonergic drugs are combined, such as SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, and TCAs. The treatment of choice for serotonin syndrome is Cyproheptadine, a serotonin receptor antagonist.

questions.text: Keratoderma Blennorrhagicum is most commonly associated with: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Reactive Arthritis

 

Explanation: 

 

Keratoderma blennorrhagicum is a characteristic skin manifestation of Reactive Arthritis. Reactive Arthritis (formerly known as Reiter's syndrome) typically presents with a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis, often following gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections. Keratoderma blennorrhagicum appears as pustular skin lesions that resemble psoriasis, typically on the palms and soles. It is considered part of the characteristic clinical presentation of reactive arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis - RA is characterized by symmetric polyarthritis, morning stiffness, and systemic manifestations. Skin manifestations in RA include rheumatoid nodules, but not keratoderma blennorrhagicum, which is specific to reactive arthritis.

 

Option B. Psoriatic Arthritis - While psoriatic arthritis does have skin manifestations (primarily psoriatic plaques), keratoderma blennorrhagicum specifically refers to the pustular lesions seen in reactive arthritis. Though they can appear similar to pustular psoriasis, they are distinct clinical entities.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis - AS primarily affects the axial skeleton, causing sacroiliitis and spinal fusion. While it shares genetic associations (HLA-B27) with reactive arthritis, keratoderma blennorrhagicum is not a typical manifestation of ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratoderma blennorrhagicum, characterized by pustular skin lesions resembling psoriasis on the palms and soles, is a distinctive cutaneous manifestation of Reactive Arthritis, which typically occurs following gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections.

choices.text: Start IV fluids with large bore cannula
Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
Take the patient to the ICU and intubate

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema and there is an absence of air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

 

History is suggestive of tension pneumothorax and hence immediate decompression is required to maintain hemodynamic stability. Definitive management involves insertion of Chest tube/Pigtail in the triangle of safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start IV fluids with large bore cannula: While IV fluids are important in managing hypotension, they do not address the immediate life-threatening issue of tension pneumothorax and might actually exacerbate the patient's condition by increasing venous return and further compressing the heart.

 

Option C. Take the patient to the ICU and intubate: Intubation in the setting of tension pneumothorax without prior decompression can worsen the patient’s hemodynamic status by increasing intrathoracic pressure.

 

Option D. Start positive pressure ventilation: Positive pressure ventilation could potentially increase the pressure in the pleural cavity, worsening the tension pneumothorax and leading to rapid hemodynamic deterioration.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression is critical to stabilize the patient and prevent further cardiovascular compromise. This emergency procedure is a life-saving intervention that precedes further definitive management like chest tube insertion.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Pneumothorax/ Chap 294

questions.text: The marked structure secretes which hormone? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adrenaline

 

The marked structure in the provided histological image is the adrenal medulla. The adrenal medulla is the innermost part of the adrenal gland and is responsible for the secretion of catecholamines, primarily adrenaline (epinephrine) and norepinephrine. These hormones are crucial for the "fight or flight" response, increasing heart rate, blood pressure, and energy availability.

 

 

 

 

In the adrenal gland, there are three distinct zones in the cortex, each responsible for secreting different hormones:

 

  1. Zona glomerulosa (outermost): Secretes mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone, which regulate sodium and potassium balance.
  2. Zona fasciculata (middle): Secretes glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol, which are involved in glucose metabolism, immune response, and stress response.
  3. Zona reticularis (innermost cortex layer): Secretes androgens, which are sex hormones.

 

The adrenal medulla, which lies beneath these cortical layers, contains chromaffin cells that secrete adrenaline. This area is marked in the image, making adrenaline the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Androgen: Androgens are secreted by the zona reticularis of the adrenal cortex.

 

Option C. Glucocorticoid: Glucocorticoids, such as cortisol, are secreted by the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex.

 

Option D. Mineralocorticoid: Mineralocorticoids, such as aldosterone, are secreted by the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The adrenal medulla, the innermost part of the adrenal gland, is responsible for secreting adrenaline, a hormone essential for the body's acute stress response.

questions.text: Identify the clinical sign shown in the image below:(NEET  PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Popeye sign

 

The above image depicts the popeye sign, which is caused by a rupture of the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii.

 

Popeye sign:

 

  • Description: This refers to the prominent bulge of the biceps muscle in the arm.
  • Cause: The sign is named after the cartoon character "Popeye the Sailor Man" who had bulging forearm muscles. It's observed in cases where there's a rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon. When the tendon ruptures, the muscle can sometimes ball up, creating a bulge in the mid-arm.
  • Clinical Relevance: Often accompanied by pain and weakness, it usually requires clinical evaluation to determine the need for surgical intervention.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs sign (or lesion):

 

  • Description: It is a compression fracture of the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head.
  • Cause: This lesion occurs when the humeral head impacts against the anterior glenoid rim during an anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • Clinical Relevance: The presence of a Hill-Sachs lesion can predispose an individual to recurrent shoulder dislocations. Its size and location may dictate treatment strategy in recurrent shoulder instability.

 

 

Option C. Griesinger sign:

 

  • Description: It refers to the presence of a postauricular sulcus or groove behind the ear.
  • Cause: This sign is seen in cases of acute mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media. The groove results from the edema and venous congestion in the sigmoid sinus secondary to the adjacent inflammation.
  • Clinical Relevance: Acute mastoiditis is a serious condition that requires prompt treatment, often including surgical intervention. The presence of Griesinger's sign helps in clinical diagnosis.

 

Option D. Rising sun sign:

 

  • Description: This is a radiological sign observed on imaging of the head.
  • Cause: It's seen in cases of tuberous sclerosis, a genetic disorder. On imaging, it refers to the appearance of subependymal nodules in the lateral ventricles that project into the ventricle. The nodules resemble the sun rising over the horizon.
  • Clinical Relevance: Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by the growth of benign tumors in many parts of the body. The presence of the "Rising sun" sign can help confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Popeye sign is a clinical indication of the rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon, leading to a characteristic bulging of the biceps muscle, which requires thorough clinical assessment and possibly surgical repair.

questions.text: In a patient with renal stones, the following crystals suggest what etiology? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triple phosphate

 

The image provided in the question shows crystals that are described as "coffin-lid" shaped. These crystals are characteristic of triple phosphate stones, also known as struvite stones. Struvite stones are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria, which raise the urine pH and promote the formation of these crystals.

 

  • Triple Phosphate Crystals (Struvite): These crystals have a distinctive coffin-lid shape, which is clearly depicted in the image. They are typically seen in alkaline urine and are associated with infections, especially those caused by urease-producing organisms like Proteus, Klebsiella, or Pseudomonas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uric Acid: Uric acid crystals are usually rhomboid or rosette-shaped. They form in acidic urine and are not associated with the coffin-lid appearance shown in the image.

 

Option C. Calcium Oxalate Monohydrate: These crystals have a dumbbell or ovoid shape, not resembling the coffin-lid appearance in the image.

 

Option D. Calcium Oxalate Dihydrate: These crystals are typically envelope-shaped, resembling a square with a diagonal cross. While they might be confused with the coffin-lid shape, they are distinctively different.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coffin-lid shaped crystals in a urine analysis are indicative of triple phosphate stones, commonly associated with urinary tract infections and alkaline urine.

questions.text: What is the chromosome number of a partial hydatidiform mole? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 69 XXY

 

Partial hydatidiform moles are characterized by being triploid, meaning they have three sets of chromosomes. The chromosome number for a partial mole is typically 69, which can be either 69XXX or 69XXY.

 

  • Formation of Partial Mole:
    • Partial moles occur when two sperm fertilize a single ovum (egg). This process is called diandry.
    • As a result, both maternal and paternal genetic components are present in a partial mole.
    • The most common karyotypes for partial moles are 69XXX and 69XXY.
  • Complete Mole Characteristics:
    • Complete moles are diploid, meaning they have two sets of chromosomes.
    • They form either by:
      • One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum and then undergoing duplication, a process known as androgenesis, or
      • Two sperm (dispermy) fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum.
    • The chromosome number for complete moles is typically 46XX or 46XY.
    • Only the paternal genetic component is present, with no maternal contribution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 46 XX: This karyotype is typical for a complete mole, not a partial mole.

 

Option B. 45 XY: This karyotype is not typical for either complete or partial moles.

 

Option C. 69 XY: This option is incorrect as partial moles can be 69XY, but 69XXY is more specific and typical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Partial hydatidiform moles are triploid, typically having a chromosome number of 69, which can be 69XXX or 69XXY.

 

Ref: Page no 616, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: What causes decrease in GFR? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in glomerular filtration coefficient

 

The glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) is directly proportional to GFR according to the formula. Therefore, a decrease in Kf will lead to a decrease in GFR. The filtration coefficient represents the product of the hydraulic permeability and surface area available for filtration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect. A decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure will increase GFR by increasing the net filtration pressure gradient.

 

Option B. Increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect. An increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure increases GFR by promoting filtration.

 

Option D. Decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure: Incorrect. A decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure increases GFR by reducing the opposition to filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) and GFR are directly proportional, meaning a decrease in Kf causes a decrease in GFR.

choices.text: Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypercoagulability.
It is a water-soluble vitamin.
Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency.
Menaquinone is the dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about vitamin K? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to Vitamin K deficiency

 

Option C: Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency.

 

  • True. Prolonged use of certain antibiotics can disrupt the normal gut flora responsible for synthesizing vitamin K. This disruption can lead to a deficiency in vitamin K, which is essential for blood clotting.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypercoagulability.

 

  • False. Vitamin K deficiency does not lead to hypercoagulability. Instead, it leads to hypocoagulability, which means impaired blood clotting. Vitamin K is essential for the activation of clotting factors in the blood, and its deficiency can result in bleeding disorders, not excessive blood clotting.

 

Option B. It is a water-soluble vitamin.

 

  • False. Vitamin K is not a water-soluble vitamin; it is a fat-soluble vitamin. Fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamins A, D, E, and K, are absorbed with dietary fats and are stored in the body's fatty tissues.

 

Option D. Menaquinone is the dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables.

 

  • Partially true. While menaquinone (vitamin K2) is a form of vitamin K, the primary dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables is phylloquinone (vitamin K1). Both forms of vitamin K are essential for various biological functions.

 

Educational objective:

 

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin.

 

Sources of vitamin K:

 

  • Green leafy vegetables (Phylloquinone/ Vitamin K1)
  • Synthesis by intestinal bacteria (Menaquinones/Vitamin K2)
  • Menadione is synthetic compound metabolized to phylloquinone.

 

In normal adult dietary deficiency seldom occurs since the intestinal bacterial synthesis is sufficient to meet the needs of the body. However, deficiency can occur in conditions of malabsorption of lipids due to obstructive jaundice, chronic pancreatitis, sprue, etc.

 

Prolonged antibiotic therapy and gastrointestinal infections with diarrhea will destroy the bacterial flora and can also lead to vitamin K deficiency.

 

Vitamin K is necessary for coagulation. Factors dependent on vitamin K are Factor II (prothrombin); Factor VII (SPCA); Factor IX (Christmas factor); Factor X (Stuart Power factor) therefore deficiency will to lead to bleeding disorders.

questions.text: Which metabolic product is responsible for causing cataract in a patient with a long-standing history of diabetes? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sorbitol

 

Explanation: 

 

In patients with long-standing diabetes, excess glucose metabolism leads to cataract formation through the sorbitol pathway:

 

  1. Excess glucose is converted to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase
  2. Normally, sorbitol would be further metabolized to fructose, but in diabetes: 
    • The lens lacks sufficient sorbitol dehydrogenase enzyme
    • Sorbitol accumulates inside the lens
    • Causes osmotic stress and water accumulation
    • Leads to membrane damage and cataract formation

 

The mechanism involves:

 

  • Accumulation of sorbitol
  • Increased osmotic pressure
  • Fluid collection in lens
  • Structural damage to lens proteins

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Galactitol: Incorrect. While similar to sorbitol, galactitol is not the primary metabolic product causing diabetic cataracts.

 

Option B. Fructose: Incorrect. Fructose is a potential end product of sorbitol metabolism, not the primary cause of diabetic cataract formation.

 

Option D. Mannitol: Incorrect. Mannitol is a sugar alcohol used as a diuretic, not involved in the diabetic cataract formation process.

 

Educational Objective: 


Diabetes, sorbitol accumulation in the lens due to insufficient enzyme activity leads to osmotic stress and cataract formation through the aldose reductase pathway.

questions.text: Identify the prominent nerve pointed in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Great auricular nerve

 

The thickened nerve marked with the arrow in the above image is the great auricular nerve.

 

 

Great auricular nerve:

 

  • The great auricular nerve is the cervical plexus's largest ascending branch, arising from the anterior rami of spinal nerves C2 and C3.
  • The nerve emerges just behind the sternocleidomastoid muscle's middle portion, curves around its posterior border, and emerges on the muscle's anterior surface.
  • The great auricular nerve perforates the deep cervical fascia and ascends along the external jugular vein, passing under the platysma muscle.
  • The great auricular nerve divides into terminal branches as it approaches the parotid gland.

 

Clinical considerations:

 

  • ﻿﻿Leprosy - Nerve thickening is present. The nerve is palpable over the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (As seen in the above image)
  • ﻿﻿Frey's syndrome - An aberrant connection between the auriculotemporal nerve and great auricular nerve causes gustatory sweating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesser Occipital Nerve: The lesser occipital nerve is another branch of the cervical plexus, arising from the second cervical spinal nerve (C2). It provides sensory innervation to the skin over the posterior part of the scalp.

 

Option C. Facial Nerve: The facial nerve, also known as the seventh cranial nerve (CN VII), is a mixed nerve responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression. It also carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It does not primarily provide sensory innervation to the skin.

 

Option D. Auriculotemporal Nerve: The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3). It supplies sensory innervation to the external ear and the skin of the temple region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The great auricular nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus, specifically originating from the second and third cervical spinal nerves (C2-C3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the external ear, and the angle of the mandible.

questions.text: A patient undergoing treatment with ketoconazole for a fungal infection develops symptoms of Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD). Which of the following medications should be avoided? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cisapride

 

Cisapride is the correct answer because it's contraindicated in patients taking ketoconazole. Ketoconazole is a potent inhibitor of CYP3A4 enzyme, which metabolizes cisapride. When used together, cisapride levels can increase dramatically, resulting in QT prolongation and potentially fatal cardiac arrhythmias including torsades de pointes. This dangerous drug interaction necessitates avoiding cisapride in patients on ketoconazole therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Itopride: Unlike cisapride, itopride is not significantly metabolized by CYP450 enzymes, making it safer to use with ketoconazole. It's primarily eliminated via renal excretion, reducing the risk of drug-drug interactions.

 

Option C. Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide is primarily metabolized through different pathways and has minimal interaction with CYP3A4 inhibitors like ketoconazole. It remains a safe prokinetic option for GERD management in patients on antifungal therapy.

 

Option D. Domperidone: While domperidone has some CYP3A4 metabolism and caution is advised, it doesn't have the same level of life-threatening interaction profile as cisapride does with ketoconazole.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cisapride is absolutely contraindicated with CYP3A4 inhibitors like ketoconazole due to the risk of potentially fatal cardiac arrhythmias; alternative prokinetics should be selected for GERD management in such patients.

questions.text: A pituitary tumor that overproduced growth hormone was surgically removed from a patient. The resection was discovered to be insufficient. What is the patient's first-line treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Octreotide

 

Octreotide is a synthetic somatostatin analog that inhibits the secretion of growth hormone (GH) from the pituitary gland. It is the first-line treatment for patients with acromegaly when surgery alone is insufficient to control GH levels. Octreotide binds to somatostatin receptors, reducing GH production and controlling symptoms of acromegaly.

 


Other Options:

 

Option A. Leuprolide: Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist primarily used in the treatment of hormone-sensitive cancers such as prostate cancer, and conditions like endometriosis and uterine fibroids. It is not used for reducing GH levels in acromegaly.

 

Option B. Goserelin: Goserelin is another GnRH agonist used for similar indications as leuprolide, including prostate cancer and breast cancer, as well as for managing endometriosis. It is not indicated for GH reduction in acromegaly.

 

Option C. Nafarelin: Nafarelin also a GnRH agonist, is used for the treatment of endometriosis and central precocious puberty. Like the other GnRH agonists, it is not used to manage GH levels in acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Octreotide is used for the treatment of the following conditions: (SOMATostatin)

 

S: Secretory diarrhea due to carcinoid tumor, VIPomas, following cancer chemotherapy, AIDS etc.

 

O: Oesophageal varices (Acute Variceal bleeding)

 

M: Malignancy like Insulinoma and Glucagonoma

 

A: Acromegaly due to GH secreting pituitary adenoma

 

T: Thyrotrope adenoma

 

  • Leuprolide, Goeserelin and Nafarelin are GnRH agonists.

questions.text: Identify the blue-colored area shown in the image below?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mid-pelvis

 

The true pelvis is divided into 3 planes

 

  1. Plane of Inlet
  2. Plane of Mid cavity (Mid-Pelvis)
  3. Plane of Outlet

 

The Plane of Mid Cavity (Or Mid-Pelvis) is what is shown in the image

 

Pelvic Cavity

 

This has 2 planes

 

  1. Plane of Greatest Dimension: 
    • At the level of S2/3
    • Circular plane; AP diameter = Transverse diameter = 12.5 cm
    • Widest part of pelvis
  2. Plane of Least dimension
    • At the level of S3/4
    • At the level of ischial spine
    • Very important plane CLINICALLY
      1. Narrowest part of pelvis
      2. Internal rotation takes place here
      3. Origin of levator ani
      4. Landmark for pudendal block
      5. When engagement occurs, the head is felt at 0 station, i.e., at this plane
      6. Deep Transverse Arrest occurs here

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstetric outlet:

 

  • Refers to the lower part of the pelvic outlet, which is wider than the anatomical outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option B. Anatomical outlet:

 

  • Refers to the narrowest part of the pelvic outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option C. Pelvic inlet:

 

  • Marks the entrance to the true pelvis.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The plane of the mid-pelvis (or mid cavity) is a crucial area within the true pelvis, significant for various clinical considerations during labor and delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a recent type B aortic dissection presents with abdominal pain and lower limb ischemia with diminished femoral and popliteal pulses. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Repair the descending aorta

 

Option C:

 

New-onset abdominal pain and limb ischemia in a patient with type B aortic dissection indicate a complicated dissection, likely due to malperfusion of the mesenteric and lower extremity arteries. This requires urgent surgical or endovascular repair.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Enalaprilat: Although used for blood pressure control, it doesn't address the underlying issue of malperfusion.

 

Option B. Increasing nitroprusside: May help with blood pressure control but doesn't solve the urgent need for revascularization.

 

Option D.  Switching to amlodipine: Not appropriate in an acute setting requiring immediate intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the signs of complicated type B aortic dissection (malperfusion syndromes) and the need for immediate surgical/endovascular repair.

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.text: A young male came to the hospital with a clean-cut wound without any bleeding. The patient received a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. What is the best management for this patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Single-dose tetanus toxoid

 

The patient presents with a clean-cut wound and has a history of receiving a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. Based on the guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis, the appropriate management for this patient falls under the category where the patient has received a complete course of tetanus vaccination more than 5 years ago but less than 10 years ago.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Management of Tetanus-Prone Wounds:

 

 

CC = Complete course; TIG = Tetanus Immunoglobulin

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein's purpura (HSP). Glucocorticoids are used to treat HSP.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azathioprine: Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant that may be used in severe cases of HSP with nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for the initial presentation of HSP.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is used in various autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, but it is not typically used for the treatment of HSP.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive agent used in certain conditions, including severe nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a long history of chronic smoking presents to the clinic with respiratory symptoms. Upon examination, it is noted that the lining epithelium of his respiratory tract has undergone a notable change. The transition from columnar epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium is evident, as depicted in the provided image. To identify this specific change, what is the term used to describe this alteration in the lining epithelium? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metaplasia

 

The change described in the question is called metaplasia. It is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

 

 

 

Metaplasia of normal columnar (left) to squamous epithelium (right) in a bronchus

 

  • Another example of metaplasia: BARRETTs esophagus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysplasia: Dysplasia refers to abnormal development or growth of cells, tissues, or organs. It is characterized by changes in cell size, shape, and organization. Dysplasia can be a precursor to cancer but does not describe the replacement of one cell type by another.

 

Option B. Hypertrophy: Hypertrophy is the increase in the size of cells, leading to an increase in the size of the tissue or organ. It does not involve a change in the cell type.

 

Option C. Atrophy: Atrophy refers to the reduction in the size of cells, tissues, or organs, often due to decreased use, insufficient nutrition, or aging. It does not involve a change in the cell type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metaplasia is the term used to describe the reversible change where one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type, often as an adaptive response to chronic irritation or inflammation, such as the transition from columnar to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of chronic smokers.
